item.title:
RT by @gakonst: Fusaka @NethermindEth Team View
1. We aim to ship Fusaka in 2025. 2. The Fusaka scope should be finalized ASAP so that we can proceed with scoping Glamsterdam. 3. PeerDAS is the most important feature of this fork and serves as the key readiness indicator. 4. We would like to see EOF in Fusaka, along with a few additional EIPs in this fork.
Fusaka Core EIPs
- EIP-7594: PeerDAS - Peer Data Availability Sampling - EIP-7692: EOF EIPs (+ EIP-7873 TXCREATE Transaction) - EIP-7883: ModExp Gas Cost Increase
Other EIPs that should be considered
- EIP-7825: Transaction Gas Limit Cap - RIP-7212: Precompile for secp256r1 Curve Support - EIP-7823: Set upper bounds for MODEXP
Reasoning
- PeerDAS is crucial for scaling. The fork should be shipped as soon as it is ready. - EOF is in an advanced stage of implementation and enhances both EVM functionality and ZK-provability. It also provides a structured path for future EVM improvements. - MODEXP is currently the biggest bottleneck to gas scaling and could hinder further gas limit increases. - Transaction Gas Limit Cap will be useful as the gas limit increases and will improve predictability for worst-case scenarios. - secp256r1 improves UX, curve is already implemented in most clients, but cross-client gas-price benchmarking is necessary.
Glamsterdam
We believe Glamsterdam's primary focus should be: - Censorship resistance, which could be addressed through: EIP-7805: Fork-choice enforced Inclusion Lists (FOCIL) - Slot organization improvements like thos proposed in EIP-7732: Enshrined Proposer-Builder Separation (ePBS)
Beyond Fusaka and Glamsterdam
- We aim to implement full history expiry in the upcoming forks, as it is a non-consensus change. - The Nethermind team remains committed to advancing stateless Ethereum and continuing research into binary trees and Verkle trees. We envision statelessness as a key focus for one of the post-Glamsterdam hard forks.

item.description:
Fusaka @NethermindEth Team View

1. We aim to ship Fusaka in 2025.
2. The Fusaka scope should be finalized ASAP so that we can proceed with scoping Glamsterdam.
3. PeerDAS is the most important feature of this fork and serves as the key readiness indicator.
4. We would like to see EOF in Fusaka, along with a few additional EIPs in this fork.

Fusaka Core EIPs

- EIP-7594: PeerDAS - Peer Data Availability Sampling
- EIP-7692: EOF EIPs (+ EIP-7873 TXCREATE Transaction)
- EIP-7883: ModExp Gas Cost Increase

Other EIPs that should be considered

- EIP-7825: Transaction Gas Limit Cap
- RIP-7212: Precompile for secp256r1 Curve Support
- EIP-7823: Set upper bounds for MODEXP

Reasoning

- PeerDAS is crucial for scaling. The fork should be shipped as soon as it is ready.
- EOF is in an advanced stage of implementation and enhances both EVM functionality and ZK-provability. It also provides a structured path for future EVM improvements.
- MODEXP is currently the biggest bottleneck to gas scaling and could hinder further gas limit increases.
- Transaction Gas Limit Cap will be useful as the gas limit increases and will improve predictability for worst-case scenarios.
- secp256r1 improves UX, curve is already implemented in most clients, but cross-client gas-price benchmarking is necessary.

Glamsterdam

We believe Glamsterdam's primary focus should be:
- Censorship resistance, which could be addressed through: EIP-7805: Fork-choice enforced Inclusion Lists (FOCIL)
- Slot organization improvements like thos proposed in EIP-7732: Enshrined Proposer-Builder Separation (ePBS)

Beyond Fusaka and Glamsterdam

- We aim to implement full history expiry in the upcoming forks, as it is a non-consensus change.
- The Nethermind team remains committed to advancing stateless Ethereum and continuing research into binary trees and Verkle trees. We envision statelessness as a key focus for one of the post-Glamsterdam hard forks.

item.title: RT by @gakonst: During one of the past core dev meetings @gakonst suggested that EL (execution layer) client teams (Besu, Erigon, Geth, Nethermind, Reth, ...) could benefit greatly from acquainting themselves with the CL (consensus layer) client (Grandine, Lighthouse, Lodestar, Nimbus, Prysm, Teku, ...) codebases. With the likely criticality of PeerDAS (deliver 2025) it may be more important than ever.
